div1.p: Kissinger responds to questions regarding the yellow fever experiments. He asserts that he volunteered before Moran.

div1.head: Notes on John R. Kissinger, [by Philip Showalter Hench], June 2, 1938
div1.p: NOTES FROM MR. JOHN J. KISSINGER

Moran was in the Quartermaster's department down in Quenados. I
had been discharged from the service and had taken his place in the operating
room. Moran after being discharged, got a position as in this
quartermaster's department. Moran and I were great friends, so he would come
back and forth to the camp. He lived in Quenados. I had my room in the
operating department. He would come over to visit me quite often.
When the doctors first come down tofrom Quenados to Columbia Barracks, when they
first began to collect mosquitoes for their first experiment, there were nine
men who offered themselves to be bitten by mosquitos: Dr. Pinto, now of Omaha,
Dr. Carroll, Dr. Lazear, I think Lieutenant Triby, myself and 4 others around the
camp whose names I do not remember.

Q. You were not quarantined--you merely walked in, let mosquitoes bite
you and went about your business? Dr. Pinto and I were there when they let the
mosquitoes in and we allowed them to bite us. It must have been in July or August.

Q. You were not quarantined, etc.? No. There were about 9 of us bitten
within a few days or a week.
Q. Nothing happened? A. No.

Q. Was Moran bitten then? No, Moran did not come in until after Dr.
Lazear had died and they were talking about Camp Lazear, which was to be
created. Moran was over to my quarters and we were talking about it. I
told him that I had already spoken to Reed about volunteering.
Moran and I never went together to Dr. Reed. Before this time I had casually
volunteered. I told Dr. Reed when they were creating Camp Lazear, and I
heard the conversation all the time. No call was given out.

Q. How did they spread the word around that they wanted volunteers?
“They practically told it out.”

Q. You had already casually volunteered to Reed? Yes. I said to the
doctors that they could try them on me any time.

Q. When was it that you and Moran started talking this over? It must
have been along in the latter part of October. After Lazear died and when
Dr. Reed was talking about creating the experimental camp, Moran came over
to my quarters. We were talking about the experimenting and I told him that
I had volunteered. Moran said “Kissinger, I am going in it myself. I am
going to volunteer. I think it is the right thing for us to do. Why shouldn't
we take chances as well as when we come into the service? I have made up my
mind to study to be a physician and it will if we are fortunate enough to
get out of it alive, it will give me a start in that direction.” The next
3.
day he went up to Reed alone and volunteered, and when we were taken out to
the quarters, Moran joined us. He dropped his work there as young quartermaster
and joined us. Mr. Moran was not in on the preliminary work.

I was not in the room when he saw Reed. I was on duty when he went up.
Reed told both of us: “There is money enough for you fellows that will take
this here task.” Moran said practically the same thing that I did, that we
would not consider going in it for money, but for humanity and science.

Q. Did you at any time have a formally have a talk with the doctors?
Yes. When I overheard them talk in the experiment room about creating Camp Lazear.
I went to see Major Reed at his officer's quarters. He was on the porch. That
is when I went up and told him. It was along in the latter part of October I
decided to remind Dr. Reed of my promise and told him that I was ready to go
with him, to go out to Camp Lazear and volunteer. He said, “Kissinger, you know
there has money been provided to pay you fellows a compensation for the experiments.
I think it will be quite a sum of money.” I told him, “Doctor, you couldn't
buy my little finger. I am not here to sell my health or my life but if you
can use it for humanity and medical science I am willing to volunteer under
those conditions.” He told me, “Kissinger, I consider that very much of a
courageous act. I surely appreciate that.”

“As far as saluting and saying, “I salute you, gentlemen,” that is all a
mistake. That was before Moran volunteered. I think it was a day or so before
Moran came to me and told me he was also going to volunteer.”

Q. What was the mortality among the soldiers? A. “Well, you can't hardly
just give that definite. 25%, 30%, 40% were dying. It varied with the difference
in handling the patients. With the small epidemic we had in our camp, there were
about 35% who died from that.”

Q. What was the treatment? “Injections by rectum of ice water (saline) were
given.”

Q. When you first knew that you were sick, what were your sensations?
“The fact that I had already stayed in Columbia Barracks 30 days under voluntary
quarantine more or less indicates the time of my first volunteering (November 20).
We arrived at Camp Lazear on November 20. Owing to the fact that I had been
30 days under observation they thought it was safe to place the five mosquitoes
upon my arm. Dr. Agramonte came in about 2 in the afternoon and placed the five
mosquitoes upon my arm. Three days later, November 23, they placed the same
mosquitoes upon my arm. About twelve days later, on December 5, they placed three
old mosquitoes and two new ones on my arm at 5 P.M. On December 8, at 11:30 P.M.
I first noticed a chill. In the evening Moran and I had chased a dog out of the
5.
camp and then retired about 9:30 P.M. Steward Colby was an uncommissioned officer
in charge of Camp Lazear. He was across the tent, and he was dead to the world.
I woke up about 11:30 to close the tent flaps. I felt a chill, so I lay back, pulled
the blankets up over me, and I don't know just how many minutes I was in that chill.
I had my bedside table beside me so I lit a candle and took my temperature. Just
as I lit the candle the guard asked about the lights. As soon as I removed the
thermometer I said to him, ‘You report to Dr. Ames that I had a severe chill and that
my temperature is 100.’ He waslke walked over to Dr. Ames' tent and he came in his
pajamas. Until he got there it seemed as if every bone in my body had been crushed.
It seemed as if my head were going to burst open. I became sick to my stomach, and
they removed me at 4 A.M. to the Yellow Fever quarters, down below Quenados, that is,
they took me away from Camp Lazear to Columbia Barracks the yellow fever quarters about
1/2 mile from the main hospital grounds.

Q. Did you think you were going to die? No, the only time that I really gave
it very much of a thought was when I was passing a tent, just a night or so before I
went down, and overheard Dr. Ames tell some of the men that he wouldn't be in my shoes
for a good many dollars. I went back in the tent and it run through my mind that when
my attending doctor would repeat those words, what chance did I have? But I threw it
off. I didn't worry about myself during my illness. My main worry after I began to
6.
get over it was more of something to eat.

Discussing Moran's letter with me, Mr. Kissinger says this part of the letter
is incorrect: “We did not go in together. I had already volunteered. We did
talk it over, and Moran told me that Dr. Ames had talked to him, and that he was
going to volunteer also. To my best recollection, he went alone. But as far as
publishing anything I am quite willing to allow Moran's incorrect version to stand.
However, I take issue on the point that he was the spokesman for us both. I had
already spoken for myself as I had been there and known Dr. Reed already for a
considerable period of time. Moran has just as much credit coming to him as I do,
but I don't like to have him saying that he was the leading spokesman, as I was
acquainted with Dr.Major Reed. After Sidney Howard went down there and talked to him,
Howard changed the whole atmosphere of the book. He was practically the leader
of it. As far as that is concerned, no credit was given to any of us.”

If you are trying to reach the truth, if John J. Moran or any of the others
can prove to me that I am wrong, I am willing to give in.
Dr.Major Reed and Lieutenant Trilby was sitting on the porch of the officers' quarters
and I went over, saluted him and told him. That is what I have in my memory.
This was one or two days before Moran had volunteered. That night when Moran came
over I spoke to him about this.

I think that Moran felt that owing to the fact that I was getting so many
7.
writeups in the paper I was trying to throw the glory upon myself.

Commenting on Major Reed's “office tent”, Mr. Kissinger doesn't remember
that Reed had any office tent, nor can he remember that Moran acted as secretary
to Major Reed at Camp Lazear. “He did help me with making up my reports at
Columbia Barracks and in helping me make out my payroll. Major Reed did not stay
at Camp Lazear but visited the camp every so often. The ones who stayed at the
camp were Dr. Ames, the attending doctor, who was immune, Dr. Carroll and Dr.
Agramonte, who slept there. They didn't stay there continuously. Major Reed
never stayed in that camp over night.

Mr. Kissinger stated that in Mr. Moran's recent radio talk, he mentioned
betting with Suntag, not Jernegan.
